edu.ncsu.csc.itrust.dao.mysql

? TransactionDAO

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.ncsu.csc.itrust.dao.mysql.TransactionDAO

  • public class TransactionDAO
extends java.lang.Object
    Used for the logging mechanism. DAO stands for Database Access Object. All DAOs are intended to be reflections of the database, that is, one DAO per table in the database (most of the time). For more complex sets of queries, extra DAOs are added. DAOs can assume that all data has been validated and is correct. DAOs should never have setters or any other parameter to the constructor than a factory. All DAOs should be accessed by DAOFactory (@see DAOFactory) and every DAO should have a factory - for obtaining JDBC connections and/or accessing other DAOs.
    ??:
    Andy

      • logTransaction

        public void logTransaction(TransactionType type,
                  long loggedInMID)
                    throws DBException
        Log a transaction, just giving it the person who is logged in and the type
        ??:
        type - The TransactionType enum representing the type this transaction is.
        loggedInMID - The MID of the user who is logged in.
        ??:
        DBException

      • logTransaction

        public void logTransaction(TransactionType type,
                  long loggedInMID,
                  long secondaryMID,
                  java.lang.String addedInfo)
                    throws DBException
        Log a transaction, with all of the info. The meaning of secondaryMID and addedInfo changes depending on the transaction type.
        ??:
        type - The TransactionType enum representing the type this transaction is.
        loggedInMID - The MID of the user who is logged in.
        secondaryMID - Typically, the MID of the user who is being acted upon.
        addedInfo - A note about a subtransaction, or specifics of this transaction (for posterity).
        ??:
        DBException

        public java.util.List<TransactionBean> getTransactionsAffecting(long mid,
                                                       java.util.Date start,
                                                       int range)
                                                         throws DBException
        The Most Thorough Fetch
        ??:
        mid - MID of the logged in user
        start - Index to start pulling entries from
        range - Number of entries to retrieve
        ??:
        List of TransactionBeans affecting the user starting from the th entry
        ??:
        DBException
